text: Zechariah prophesied alongside which other prophet during the rebuilding of the Temple?
verseText: Now the prophets, Haggai and Zechariah the son of Iddo, prophesied to the Jews who were in Judah and Jerusalem, in the name of the God of Israel who was over them.

text: Zechariah's ministry began in the second year of which Persian king?
verseText: In the eighth month, in the second year of Darius, the word of the LORD came to the prophet Zechariah, the son of Berechiah, son of Iddo...

text: Zechariah chapters 1-8 primarily consist of a series of what?
verseText: (Chapters 1-6 describe a series of eight symbolic visions Zechariah received in one night).

text: In Zechariah's first vision, what did the horsemen among the myrtle trees report?
options: The whole earth was at peace and rest
verseText: And they answered the angel of the LORD who was standing among the myrtle trees, ‘We have patrolled the earth, and behold, all the earth remains at rest.’”

text: What did the vision of the four horns and four craftsmen represent (Zechariah 1:18-21)?
options: Four empires that scattered Judah and the powers that would overthrow them
Four corners of the earth and God's messengers
Four types of sacrifices and the priests
verseText: And I said to the angel... ‘What are these?’ And he said to me, ‘These are the horns that scattered Judah...’ Then the LORD showed me four craftsmen... ‘These have come to terrify them, to cast down the horns of the nations who lifted up their horn against the land of Judah to scatter it.’”

text: In the vision of Joshua the High Priest (Zechariah 3), who stood accusing him?
verseText: Then he showed me Joshua the high priest standing before the angel of the LORD, and Satan standing at his right hand to accuse him.

text: What was done for Joshua the High Priest in the vision to symbolize cleansing and restoration?
verseText: And the angel said to those who were standing before him, “Remove the filthy garments from him.” And to him he said, “Behold, I have taken your iniquity away from you, and I will clothe you with pure vestments.” And I said, “Let them put a clean turban on his head.” So they put a clean turban on his head and clothed him with garments.

text: The vision of the golden lampstand and two olive trees (Zechariah 4) primarily encouraged whom?
options: Zerubbabel, assuring him the Temple would be finished by God's Spirit
verseText: Then he said to me, “This is the word of the LORD to Zerubbabel: Not by might, nor by power, but by my Spirit, says the LORD of hosts... The hands of Zerubbabel have laid the foundation of this house; his hands shall also complete it.

text: Zechariah 9:9 famously prophesies about Jerusalem's king coming in what manner?
options: Humble and mounted on a donkey
verseText: Rejoice greatly, O daughter of Zion! Shout aloud, O daughter of Jerusalem! Behold, your king is coming to you; righteous and having salvation is he, humble and mounted on a donkey, on a colt, the foal of a donkey.

text: What price is Zechariah symbolically paid for his shepherding, which he then throws into the Temple treasury (Zechariah 11:12-13)?
verseText: Then I said to them, “If it seems good to you, give me my wages; but if not, keep them.” And they weighed out as my wages thirty pieces of silver. Then the LORD said to me, “Throw it to the potter”—the lordly price at which I was priced by them! So I took the thirty pieces of silver and threw them into the house of the LORD, to the potter.

text: What does the vision of the man with the measuring line signify for Jerusalem (Zechariah 2)?
options: Its future expansion and God's presence as a wall of fire
verseText: Then I said, “Where are you going?” And he said to me, “To measure Jerusalem, to see what is its width and what is its length.”... saying, “Run, say to that young man, ‘Jerusalem shall be inhabited as villages without walls, because of the multitude of people and livestock in it. And I will be to her a wall of fire all around, declares the LORD, and I will be the glory in her midst.’”

text: Who is referred to as 'the Branch' in Zechariah 3:8 and 6:12, a figure who will rebuild the temple and rule?
verseText: Hear now, O Joshua the high priest, you and your friends who sit before you, for they are men who are a sign: behold, I will bring my servant the Branch... and say to him, ‘Thus says the LORD of hosts, “Behold, the man whose name is the Branch: for he shall branch out from his place, and he shall build the temple of the LORD... It is he who shall bear royal honor, and shall sit and rule on his throne.

text: What does the vision of the flying scroll represent (Zechariah 5:1-4)?
options: The curse going out over the whole land against thieves and those who swear falsely
verseText: Then he said to me, “This is the curse that goes out over the face of the whole land. For everyone who steals shall be cleaned out according to what is on one side, and everyone who swears falsely shall be cleaned out according to what is on the other side.

text: What does the vision of the woman in the ephah (basket) represent (Zechariah 5:5-11)?
options: Wickedness being removed from the land and taken to Babylon (Shinar)
verseText: And behold, the leaden cover was lifted, and there was a woman sitting in the ephah! And he said, “This is Wickedness.” And he thrust her back into the ephah... He said to me, “To the land of Shinar, to build a house for it. And when this is prepared, they will set the ephah down there on its base.”

text: What do the four chariots patrolling the earth represent in Zechariah 6?
options: The four winds/spirits of heaven serving the Lord
verseText: And the angel answered and said to me, “These are going out to the four winds of heaven, after presenting themselves before the Lord of all the earth.”

text: In Zechariah 7, the people ask about continuing to fast. What does God say is more important than fasting?
options: Executing true justice, showing kindness and mercy, not oppressing the vulnerable
verseText: “Thus says the LORD of hosts, Render true judgments, show kindness and mercy to one another, do not oppress the widow, the fatherless, the sojourner, or the poor, and let none of you devise evil against another in your heart.”

text: Zechariah 8 promises a future for Jerusalem where what unusual sight will occur?
options: Old men and women will sit in the streets, and boys and girls will play there
verseText: Thus says the LORD of hosts: Old men and old women shall again sit in the streets of Jerusalem, each with staff in hand because of great age. And the streets of the city shall be full of boys and girls playing in its streets.

text: Zechariah 12:10 prophesies that the inhabitants of Jerusalem will look upon whom?
options: Me [the LORD], whom they have pierced
verseText: “And I will pour out on the house of David and the inhabitants of Jerusalem a spirit of grace and pleas for mercy, so that, when they look on me, on him whom they have pierced, they shall mourn for him, as one mourns for an only child...

text: What does Zechariah 13:1 say will be opened for the house of David and the inhabitants of Jerusalem?
options: A fountain to cleanse them from sin and uncleanness
verseText: “On that day there shall be a fountain opened for the house of David and the inhabitants of Jerusalem, to cleanse them from sin and uncleanness.

text: In Zechariah 13:7, God calls for the shepherd to be struck. Who does Jesus apply this prophecy to?
verseText: “Awake, O sword, against my shepherd, against the man who stands next to me,” declares the LORD of hosts. “Strike the shepherd, and the sheep will be scattered; I will turn my hand against the little ones.

text: Zechariah 14 describes a future day when the Lord will fight against the nations attacking Jerusalem. What dramatic geographical change will occur?
options: The Mount of Olives will split in two
The Dead Sea will become fresh
verseText: On that day his feet shall stand on the Mount of Olives that lies before Jerusalem on the east, and the Mount of Olives shall be split in two from east to west by a very wide valley, so that one half of the Mount shall move northward, and the other half southward.

text: What will flow out from Jerusalem on that future day described in Zechariah 14?
verseText: On that day living waters shall flow out from Jerusalem, half of them to the eastern sea and half of them to the western sea. It shall continue in summer as in winter.

text: What will happen to the nations that fought against Jerusalem, according to Zechariah 14?
options: They will be forced into slavery
They will go up year after year to worship the King, the LORD of hosts, and keep the Feast of Booths
verseText: Then everyone who survives of all the nations that have come against Jerusalem shall go up year after year to worship the King, the LORD of hosts, and to keep the Feast of Booths.

text: What inscription will be on the bells of the horses in the final vision of Zechariah 14?
verseText: And on that day there shall be inscribed on the bells of the horses, “Holy to the LORD.” And the pots in the house of the LORD shall be as the bowls before the altar.
